subject: Re: [junit] How do i check if i am getting right output
msgSnippet: ... Addenda. Note that in C ` n` means a newline character . It s when that character is written to a text stream that conversion happens. Similarly, when
messageBody:
On Wednesday 21 September 2005 15:40, Chris Dollin wrote:
> On Wednesday 21 September 2005 15:20, Elliotte Harold wrote:
> > Chris Dollin wrote:
> > > It's always puzzled me why Java got this wrong (yes, I think "wrong"
> > > is the appropriate term) when even C got it right. It means, for
> > > example, that various strings cannot be constants.
> >
> > Au contraire. Java's right. C's wrong. In Java you know a \n is a
> > linefeed. No if's, and's, or but's.
>
> I don't mind having a `linefeed` character. I do mind not having
> a notation for `the end of the line, however it's supposed to
> happen in this streamlike thing that I am writing down`.

Addenda.

Note that in C `\n` means "a newline character". It's when that
character is written to a text stream that conversion happens.
Similarly, when reading from a text stream the local end-of-line
convention (which need have nothing to do with newline or
carriage return characters; it might be a count of line length)
is applied and \n's a returned as appropriate.

If you don't want the conversion, in C you write binary files
rather than text ones.

--
Chris "electric hedgehog" Dollin
The software engineer's song: "who knows where the time goes".
